awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Smart Mask for Respiratory Monitoring and Prevention of Airborne Diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a data collection system called Smart Mask, which provides senior care communities with a safe operational environment and identifies actions that may help caregivers understand the risk of respiratory disease transmission. The overall goal is to combat the seasonal resurgence of COVID-19-like diseases by tracking the health and safe practices followed by essential workers in such facilities. At a societal level, this technology will help to monitor an active hotspot region where symptomatic cases spike suddenly.  The technology will also assist decision-makers in setting up corrective actions. The proposed mask has several wireless connectivity options with the option to share data with third party apps for reporting health abnormalities and give public health officials a real-time awareness of possible breakouts. Additionally, Smart Mask assists in raising awareness of harmful hygiene habits, to help in preventing contamination and leading to a healthier society. The Smart Mask offers essential care facilities a way to ensure their own health, sustain business growth by reducing the risk of facility spread, and inspire trust among potential customers and current employees.

This I-corps project provides a data collection and analysis system using a network of Smart Masks. Each Smart Mask has wireless connectivity with a smartphone and the following sensors: health metric sensors to non-invasively measure respiratory rate, oxygen saturation and body temperature.  The Smart Masks provide notifications of abnormal readings to the user.  They also have gesture sensors that track the gestures of touching or moving hands close to the face, using thin film and flexible capacitance coupling plates on the mask.  Finally, the Smart Masks have proximity sensing using capacitive coupling that performs mask-to-mask and mask-to-infrastructure distance ranging using signal strength measurements and coupling of capacitive fields.  The I-Corps customer discovery activities will explore the commercial potential of the proposed Smart Mask technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advanced sensor technology and wireless interconnections via the Internet of Things (IoT) paradigm opens up the possibility of innovative designs that can help to mitigate the spread of airborne diseases. To address the above needs for personal protective equipment in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, we designed a smart mask, which can sense proximity to other humans and designated at-risk surfaces, and also alert the wearer with information about unsafe behaviors such as frequently touching the face with hand. The project aimed to explore commercialization efforts and identify the important technical features that would drive adoption of our design.

Through funding from the NSF ICORPs project, our initial plan was to build a business-to-business model, where we aimed to supply smart masks in bulk to: (i) long-term/senior care centers (which house the highest at-risk population with over 150,000 elderly Massachusetts residents living in 400 nursing homes, and about 77,000 workers who help care for them), and (ii) universities and colleges. 

We identified a specific customer segment for directing our immediate efforts, who are Executive Directors of Senior Care Facilities across the country. There are approximately 6500 medium-sized, for-profit Senior Care facilities that are the target market for the Smart Mask. We also identified key partners, including mask manufacturers, Senior Care Associations, and cloud services providers. During the program, our team conducted a total of 101 interviews, including 79 individuals in the senior care industry and 39 individuals in executive roles such as healthcare services, sales, and marketing, as well as 18 senior care facilities. Through the course of the I-Corps program, we pivoted from a hardware focus to a data analysis product, focusing on providing real-time, accurate data about how COVID-19 would spread in senior care facilities. Here, we initially thought that our target customers would be primarily interested in enhancing the functionality of the masks themselves, rather than in the data and analysis provided by the sensor modules. However, through our customer discovery interviews, we found that the real value for our customers was in the data and analysis, rather than in the hardware itself. This pivot allowed us to better address the specific needs and pain points of our target customers, as well as to identify new revenue streams and business models. We also considered different revenue models, such as selling the hardware and sensor modules directly to customers, but after further research and interviews we found that a subscription-based model for access to the data and analysis would be more viable and sustainable. In terms of revenue streams, we determined that a yearly subscription to a data collection tool provided through the mask modules is the best option for commercializing the Smart Mask. 

The next step in the commercial roadmap for the Smart Mask project is the development of a minimum viable product (MVP). This will involve identifying the key features and functions that are most important to the target market, and designing a prototype that incorporates these features. In terms of the technical design, our prototype testing with two masks and one fixed point (shelf) suggested that the system can accurately sense the presence of a mask more than 94% of the time and the correct distance between the mask and shelf at least 85% of the time.

The NSF ICORPs project provided opportunities for training and professional development in effective team building and management for a PhD candidate who served as the entrepreneurial lead of the project. She learned how to schedule meetings aggressively and leverage networking opportunities with decision makers and influencers in the target market segments. These skills have helped her to become a more confident researcher and expand her comfort zone beyond academic research. Overall, participating in the NSF ICORPs project has had a positive impact on the professional development of all participants.
